page.title: 06GEOLOGY OF HARVEL
page.content: Geology of Harvel is the typical chalk formation of the North Downs crest. An overall north facing dip slope rises from about 400 to over 600 feet. The heads of three main valleys cut steeply into this, falling to about 250 feet , without rivers or springs but subject to heavy and rapid drain-off from fields above. In the south-east, Holly Hill rises to 643 feet and has a capping of pebble, sand and loam. The main North Downs scarp runs south and east of Holly Hill, dropping sharply about 300 feet on to gentle Gault-clay slopes. The scarp continues into the Medway Gap broken by the Crookhorn Combe which faces north-east. Valleys and scarps have thin chalk soils or bare chalk, but the higher crest and ridges have a clay-with-flints subsoil.
